pullRequest.title: [Metadata] Several bugfixes
pullRequest.bodyText:
…services
When someone undeploys an MTA WITHOUT using the --delete-services CLI option, the mta
metadata must be removed from the service in order to avoid future
detection of the same MTA.
Currently, it uses a workaround by setting empty ("") mta_id in
services' metadata because the cf-java-client has a bug which does not
allow deleting metadata labels/annotations.

beforeCommit.message:

When someone undeploys an MTA WITHOUT using the --delete-services CLI option, the mta
metadata must be removed from the service in order to avoid future
detection of the same MTA.
Currently, it uses a workaround by setting empty ("") mta_id in
services' metadata because the cf-java-client has a bug which does not
allow deleting metadata labels/annotations.

[Metadata] Detach service from MTA when --delete-services not used

When someone undeploys an MTA WITHOUT using the --delete-services CLI option, the mta
metadata must be removed from the service in order to avoid future
detection of the same MTA.
Currently, it uses a workaround by setting empty ("") mta_id in
services' metadata because the cf-java-client has a bug which does not
allow deleting metadata labels/annotations.

beforeCommit.message:
[Metadata] Ensure services part of new MTA are not marked as discontinued

Having Environment metadata, if a service had no bound applications,
there was no way to determine if that service is part of the MTA as the
service itself does not have environment. With the v3 Metadata, the
service has its own metadata, therefore we can now determine if the
service is part of the MTA or not. This is an enhancement which fixes an
old issue where using --delete-services on orphaned services would
delete them because of the mentioned detection above.

beforeCommit.message:
[Metadata] Handle service metadata update action correctly

There was an UpdateServiceMetadataStep but it was not part of the
'create-or-update-services.bpmn'. This commit adds it to the bpmn and
removes several unnecessary lines of code.

nodes.bodyText: Let's add unit test for that
Is it a good idea to use Optional for such composition of nullable objects
Can we have some unit tests for the step
What will happen if resource has type "existing-service-key"

                                                 .v3Metadata(ApplicationMetadataBuilder.build(deploymentDescriptor, module,
-                                                                                             resourcesAndResourceTypes))

nodes.bodyText: Better clean everything MTA related, not only MTA_ID

commit.message:
[Metadata] Detach service from MTA when --delete-services not used

When someone undeploys an MTA WITHOUT using the --delete-services CLI option, the mta
metadata must be removed from the service in order to avoid future
detection of the same MTA.
Currently, it uses a workaround by setting empty ("") mta_id in
services' metadata because the cf-java-client has a bug which does not
allow deleting metadata labels/annotations.

[Metadata] Do not store existing-service in metadata

Environment metadata does not include existing-service in application's
metadata (bound services). This should not happen for v3 metadata
either, for consistency. Also it is unnecessary as they're not needed.

[Metadata] Ensure services part of new MTA are not marked as discontinued

Having Environment metadata, if a service had no bound applications,
there was no way to determine if that service is part of the MTA as the
service itself does not have environment. With the v3 Metadata, the
service has its own metadata, therefore we can now determine if the
service is part of the MTA or not. This is an enhancement which fixes an
old issue where using --delete-services on orphaned services would
delete them because of the mentioned detection above.

[Metadata] Handle service metadata update action correctly

There was an UpdateServiceMetadataStep but it was not part of the
'create-or-update-services.bpmn'. This commit adds it to the bpmn and
removes several unnecessary lines of code.
